result.execSummary:
The defendant Jonathan C. Rusch was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess/Illegally Obtained Prescription [Modifiers: Repeater], an unclassified misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 450.11(7)(h).

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes:
To commence consecutive to any other sentence in being
--With Huber/Work-Release privileges

--Defendant is required to report for commencement and service of jail sentence with absolute sobriety and without non-prescribed controlled substances in his/her system.  Non-compliance will result in loss of Huber/work-release privileges without further process.

--Court waives costs due to defendant's incarceration

--Booking
Consecutive to: any sentence in being

DOC Balance Inquiry
of the Plea and Sentencing Hearing held on January 22, 2016 before the Honorable Neal Nettesheim
Court's response to Clerk's Note regarding costs: Please mark down as waived.
Note to the Court regarding costs
Copy of Order to Produce with notation from unknown person  "Staying"-

Case called at 2:11 pm [Clerk SH] 
[Reserve Judge Neal Nettesheim presiding for BrIV]
Defendant Jonathan C. Rusch in court, in-custody, with Attorney David Zarwell. ADA Jeffrey Martin Shock appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Constitutional rights given; plea of "No Contest" entered on Count #2; factual basis stipulated; victim rights compliance verified; Court finds the plea has been entered freely, voluntarily, intelligently and accepts the plea, finds Defendant guilty, orders JOC entered.
On Motion of the State, the Court reads-in and dismisses Count #1

On Count #2, the Court sentences Defendant to:
--serve 60 days in Jefferson County Jail, with Huber/Work-Release privileges; to commence consecutive to any other sentence in being 
--0 days credit for time already served given
--Court waives costs due to defendant's incarceration
--Booking
Recess: 2:31 pm

Case called at 9:25 am [Clerk SH]
[Reserve Judge Neal Nettesheim presiding for BrIV]
Defendant Jonathan C. Rusch appears via video, in-custody, from DCI, with Attorney David Zarwell, who appears in court. DA Susan Victoria Happ appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Court finds the proceedings are sight and sound sufficient
Service of Complaint admitted; reading waived.
Plea of "not guilty" entered; speedy trial waived by the Defendant

Court continues bond as previously set
Recess: 9:27 am

Case called at 10:22 am [Clerk SH]
[Reserve Judge Robert Mawdsley presiding for BrIV]
Defendant Jonathan C. Rusch appears via video, in-custody. ADA Theresa A Beck appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Court finds the proceedings are sight and sound sufficient

Service of Complaint admitted; reading requested & conducted by the Court.
Right to counsel given; constructive waiver of counsel warnings given.
Mr. Rusch informs the Court that he will be at DCI at least another 50 days
Speedy trial waived by the Defendant

Court requires a $1000 signature bond, with conditions: 
-No possession or consumption of controlled substances without a valid prescription 
-Take all prescription drugs as prescribed
-No possession of drug paraphernalia especially needles
Recess: 10:35 am

Defendant Jonathan C. Rusch not in court. ADA Monica J. Hall appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
